Description: Melanoma was among the most invasive, metastatic, and treatment refractory of all human cancers until the relatively recent past, when advances in genomics, signaling inhibitor discovery, tumor immunology, and clinical research have produced unprecedented changes in disease outcomes.  Several key features made melanoma a poster child for progress, from understanding its causes to new therapeutic strategies.  Melanin protects against environmental UV. But red/blond pheomelanin is measurably carcinogenic, and likely amplifies UV. The pathway through which UV stimulates melanin synthesis includes production of endorphin which induces opiate-like UV seeking behaviors. And MITF, the master transcriptional regulator of melanocyte differentiation, is also a functional relative of Myc.  MITF is an amplified or mutated oncogene in certain melanomas, a member of a family (MiT) of oncogenic transcription factors implicated in numerous other cancers, and MITF regulates the epigenetic state of melanoma cells to influence their vulnerability to both targeted and immune therapies.
